Posts.Content: Hi I am 47 and was diagnosed with a grade 2 ductal breast cancer on 13th August this year.  I have since had a lumpectomy and had lymph nodes removed - one of which was found to have some cancer cells.  As a result I am now waiting to start chemotherapy over the next few weeks (6 cycles of FEC-T) followed by radiotherapy.  I have been advised that losing my hair is a given but have been offered the option of trying a cold cap during the treatment.  I understand that there is only a 30% chance of the cold cap being successful in saving hair and wonder if anyone has any feedback.  I guess my concern is that the chemotherapy itself is going to be bad enough without having the additional discomfort of something that is potentially not going to work anyway. Kerry x
Posts.Title: Feedback on cold cap please?

Posts.Content: Hi Susie Thank you so much for your reply - its really reassuring.  My oncologist has booked the cold cap for me so I'm going to give it a go.  I guess its that fear of the unknown at the moment.  Its funny but I think I will cope better with losing my hair than I will my eye brows and lashes so even if it were to mean that I kept them I think I would be happy.  I'm going for a wig fitting next week which will be a new experience but I have also invested in 4 beanie hats (much to my boys horror!!).  Just out of interest - did you cut your hair prior to starting treatment.  My hair is in a shoulder length bob and very thick.  People have told me that it might be better to get it cut short as it is less distressing when and if it starts to fall out? Kerry x

Posts.Title: Advice / Feedback please on stopping chemo

Posts.Content: Hi. Just wondered if anyone has stopped chemo because of side effects? I have had 2 FEC so far but was due to have 1 more FEC before 3 Docetaxol. I became very low and depressed after the first so GP took me off Citalopram and put me onto Prozac instead. I went into the second round very positively and hoped there would be no further issues. Instead it was even worse and I became so low that my husband was so worried he took me back to GP who advised that if I became any lower I might need to be admitted to a mental health unit for inpatient treatment.  Having done some research I have discovered possible drug interactions which may have caused this. My oncologist was aware of all drugs that I was taking so my confidence has been well and truly knocked. As a result I am seriously considering stopping chemo and asking to have the radiotherapy and tamoxifen now. My history is a lumpectomy to remove a 30mm grade 2 tumour with the sentinel lymph node positive. It was oestrogen positive. My treatment is adjuvant. I am due to meet a new oncologist on Monday to discuss options and realise that the decision is ultimately mine to make but I would welcome any feedback or shared experiences that any of you might have. Thanks in advance. Kerry
